image.altText: Bright yellow orange sky with Uluru in foreground.

items.synopsis: The two New South Wales men, who claim to be sovereign citizens, were fined almost $9,000 each for entering and vandalising the prohibited site.

title.children: 'No shame': Pair found guilty of using oily handprints to damage sacred Uluru cave art

image.altText: Al-Hajjeh Umm Al-Saeed Abu Amer in black clothing looks toward the camera

items.synopsis: Displaced civilians in Gaza say after mosques and schools were hit by Israeli air strikes, they have nowhere to find safety, while Israel recruits advocates for the country online.

title.children: Palestinians say nowhere in Gaza is safe from air strikes, as Israel recruits online influencers

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's not just a war on the ground and in the air, but also in cyberspace too. I'm in Israel covering the war, which is in its sixth day. In a social media post, Israel's Foreign Minister Eli Cohen said the country was recruiting online influencers to help advocate for the country. He thanked model Natali Dadon, Israel's Special Envoy for Innovation Fleur Hassan-Nahoum and human rights lawyer Arsen Ostrofsky for signing up. Michael Dickson, the CEO of Stand With Us Israel, whose profile on X (formerly Twitter) says he was named one of the 15 most influential Jews on the platform, has also signed up, and been posting to his 138,000 followers. The online battlefield is less deadly, but still very important. The way information on what's happening in the Israel-Gaza war is spread abroad shapes the international community's opinions on the fighting.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel is recruiting influencers to fight the war online

children.content: It's not just a war on the ground and in the air, but also in cyberspace too.
I'm in Israel covering the war, which is in its sixth day.
In a social media post, Israel's Foreign Minister Eli Cohen said the country was recruiting online influencers to help advocate for the country.
He thanked model Natali Dadon, Israel's Special Envoy for Innovation Fleur Hassan-Nahoum and human rights lawyer Arsen Ostrofsky for signing up.

Michael Dickson, the CEO of Stand With Us Israel, whose profile on X (formerly Twitter) says he was named one of the 15 most influential Jews on the platform, has also signed up, and been posting to his 138,000 followers.

The online battlefield is less deadly, but still very important. The way information on what's happening in the Israel-Gaza war is spread abroad shapes the international community's opinions on the fighting.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I'm reporting from Jerusalem with the rest of the ABC team, along with our contacts in Gaza. Yesterday we spoke with several civilians who've been displaced since air strikes began. Al-Hajjeh Umm Al-Saeed Abu Amer, from the Shejaiya neighbourhood in Gaza City, told the ABC she fled her home when Israeli air strikes began, but found almost nowhere was safe. "We gathered ourselves and got out of the houses. Where are we going to go? "We went to the mosques, they struck the mosques. We went to the schools, they struck them too. "We only found Shifa [hospital] to find refuge. We thought it would be a safe place, but it also turned out not to be safe." She said last night she was sleeping outside the hospital under a tree with a group of people when they were woken around 3am by people warning them to find safety. "We are calling on all the Arab countries if they had an ounce of conscience and an ounce of humanity and an ounce of bravery to stand with the Palestinian people in Gaza."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Displaced Palestinians in Gaza say nowhere is safe from air strikes

children.content: I'm reporting from Jerusalem with the rest of the ABC team, along with our contacts in Gaza. Yesterday we spoke with several civilians who've been displaced since air strikes began.
Al-Hajjeh Umm Al-Saeed Abu Amer, from the Shejaiya neighbourhood in Gaza City, told the ABC she fled her home when Israeli air strikes began, but found almost nowhere was safe.

props.alt: An older woman wearing black hijab gestures with one hand while looking into camera

children.content: Al-Hajjeh Umm Al-Saeed Abu Amer, 60, fled her home in the Shejaiya neighbourhood.
(ABC News)
"We gathered ourselves and got out of the houses. Where are we going to go?
"We went to the mosques, they struck the mosques. We went to the schools, they struck them too.
"We only found Shifa [hospital] to find refuge. We thought it would be a safe place, but it also turned out not to be safe."
She said last night she was sleeping outside the hospital under a tree with a group of people when they were woken around 3am by people warning them to find safety.
"We are calling on all the Arab countries if they had an ounce of conscience and an ounce of humanity and an ounce of bravery to stand with the Palestinian people in Gaza."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) says it is in touch with both Hamas and Israeli authorities about hostages taken by Hamas militants during Thursday's deadly attack. "We are now in contact with Hamas and Israeli officials as part of efforts on this issue," said Fabrizio Carboni, ICRC regional director, who called for their immediate release. "As a neutral intermediary we stand ready to conduct humanitarian visits; facilitate communication between hostages and family members; and to facilitate any eventual release," he added. Reporting by Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Red Cross in contact with both Hamas and Israel to help release hostages

children.content: The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC)
says it is in touch with both Hamas and Israeli authorities about
hostages taken by Hamas militants
during Thursday's deadly attack.
"We are now in contact with Hamas and Israeli officials as part of efforts on this issue," said
Fabrizio Carboni
, ICRC regional director, who called for their immediate release.
"As a neutral intermediary we stand ready to conduct humanitarian visits; facilitate communication between hostages and family members; and to facilitate any eventual release," he added.
Reporting by Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The participants of the 1965 Freedom Ride have released a statement in support of voting Yes in the Voice to Parliament referendum this Saturday. "We're voting YES to the Voice, for Charlie Perkins, " the statement reads, which is signed by Freedom Riders including Gary Williams, Jim Spigelman, Ann Curthoys, Aidan Foy, Pat Healy, Brian Aarons, Beth Hansen, Alec Mills, Chris Page and Warwick Richards. "As young Sydney University students, we took part in the Freedom Ride of February 1965 through northern NSW country towns, led by the legendary Aboriginal activist Charles (Charlie) Perkins. "We call on Australians to vote YES in Saturday's Referendum as another step forward in the long journey towards justice and equality for Australia's First Peoples. It brings us closer to achieving that Australian national aspiration, 'A fair go for all'. "We do not presume to speak for Charlie Perkins, who left us 23 years ago. But Charlie was always a passionate voice for his people, and he knew how vital it was that Indigenous Australians had a voice to speak for them. As some of those who had the privilege to accompany him on the Freedom Ride all those many years ago, we will be voting YES in his honour."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Participants of 1965 Freedom Ride back Yes vote

children.content: The participants of the 1965 Freedom Ride have released a statement in support of voting Yes in the Voice to Parliament referendum this Saturday.

props.alt: A black and whitep photo from the 60s of students sitting in front of a bus in front of a banner that says Student Action for Aborigines.

children.content: (Behind the News)
"We're voting YES to the Voice, for
Charlie Perkins,
" the statement reads, which is signed by Freedom Riders including
Gary Williams
Jim Spigelman
Ann Curthoys
Aidan Foy
Pat Healy
Brian Aarons
Beth Hansen
Alec Mills
Chris Page
and
Warwick Richards.
"As young Sydney University students, we took part in the Freedom Ride of February 1965 through northern NSW country towns, led by the legendary Aboriginal activist Charles (Charlie) Perkins.

"We call on Australians to vote YES in Saturday's Referendum as another step forward in the long journey towards justice and equality for Australia's First Peoples. It brings us closer to achieving that Australian national aspiration, 'A fair go for all'.

"We do not presume to speak for Charlie Perkins, who left us 23 years ago. But Charlie was always a passionate voice for his people, and he knew how vital it was that Indigenous Australians had a voice to speak for them. As some of those who had the privilege to accompany him on the Freedom Ride all those many years ago, we will be voting YES in his honour."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Lee Robinson Prominent No campaigner Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price is among the many Australians casting their votes before polling day on Saturday. Price today cast her vote in the referendum at an early voting centre in Alice Springs alongside her husband, Colin Lillie. The Northern Territory senator has become a leading figure in the No camp, and is the federal shadow minister for Indigenous Australians. Speaking after casting her vote, Senator Price said she hopes the country will reunite after the referendum result on Saturday. "No matter what the outcome is, Australia has gone through a pretty rough patch with this referendum ," she said. "It's been the most divisive referendum that our nation has ever experienced and we really need to pull together again as a country."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Price casts vote in Alice Springs

children.content: Reporting by Lee Robinson
Prominent No campaigner
Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price
is among the many Australians casting their votes before polling day on Saturday.
Price today cast her vote in the referendum at an early voting centre in Alice Springs alongside her husband, Colin Lillie.

props.alt: A close up of Jacinta speaking in a pale yellow blouse.

children.content: Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price.
(ABC News: Alice Springs)
The Northern Territory senator has become a leading figure in the No camp, and is the federal shadow minister for Indigenous Australians.
Speaking after casting her vote, Senator Price said she hopes the country will reunite after the referendum result on Saturday.
"No matter what the outcome is,
Australia has gone through a pretty rough patch with this referendum
," she said.
"It's been the most divisive referendum that our nation has ever experienced and we really need to pull together again as a country."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Analysis by 7.30 reporter Nadia Daly Ahead of the vote this weekend I've been taking a look at the state of play in Victoria. It's often seen as one of the more progressive states and for a while it was one of a few that was leaning towards a Yes majority in the polls. That's now changed, according to all but one opinion poll. They're now projecting a No vote will win in Victoria. It's worth noting opinion polls have their limitation and can be wrong (and have been in the past). I spoke to Victorian lobbyist and pollster Kos Samaras about why there has been a shift in the state. He told me it's being driven by Melbourne's outer suburbs, where the Yes campaign has been less visible (compared to inner city suburbs where the Yes vote is much higher) and where some voters aren't finding the case for voting Yes succinct or clear enough. Additionally, he said some areas with higher migrant populations in the state were only being handed campaign pamphlets in English. And Kos said that when people don't understand, they're more likely to vote No. But the Yes campaign is staying positive and they are hopeful the many undecided voters will be swayed towards a Yes in the coming days. I'll have more on 7.30 tonight.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A look at Victoria's state of play

children.content: Analysis by 7.30 reporter Nadia Daly
Ahead of the vote this weekend I've been taking a look at the state of play in Victoria.
It's often seen as one of the more progressive states and for a while it was one of a few that was leaning towards a Yes majority in the polls.

That's now changed, according to all but one opinion poll. They're now projecting a No vote will win in Victoria. It's worth noting opinion polls have their limitation and can be wrong (and have been in the past).

props.alt: A Vote Yes and Vote No sign side by side.

children.content: (AAP: Esther Linder)
I spoke to Victorian lobbyist and pollster
Kos Samaras
about why there has been a shift in the state.
He told me it's
being driven by Melbourne's outer suburbs,
where the Yes campaign has been
less visible
(compared to inner city suburbs where the Yes vote is much higher) and where some voters aren't finding the case for voting Yes
succinct or clear enough.
Additionally, he said some areas with higher migrant populations in the state were only being
handed campaign pamphlets in English.
And Kos said that when people don't understand, they're more likely to vote No.
But the Yes campaign is staying positive and they are hopeful the many undecided voters will be swayed towards a Yes in the coming days.
I'll have more on 7.30 tonight.
